ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Intermediate Chinese language skills
Continued to develop my ability to speak, read, write and understand Mandarin.
This course continued the development of my Chinese vocabulary, grammar, writing, speaking, and listening abilities.
I was able to significantly increase my mandarin vocabulary and work on speaking, reading, listening, and writing new grammar structures while incorporating the new words I learned.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Teachers are very helpful and understanding. Pace is fast but reasonable. Caring classmates with many opportunities for collaboration. Completely discussion-based. 
Weaknesses: Requires a lot of work and time outside of class. Somewhat repetitive.

I wish there was some Hanzi writing component, I feel very behind on handwriting since there wasn't much incentive to keep caught up.

With that aside, all my other language skills improved drastically, and I thought the time in class was great, and the assignments were well organized.
Strengths: Teacher is very engaged with students.

I really enjoyed this class. I think that the class does exactly what it sets out to do. One thing I think might be a good improvement is to encourage more collaboration and to make more homework where collaboration could be useful beyond only group dialogues.

The Chinese professors here are wonderful and make the learning experience considerably more manageable. The course is also extremely well structured and balanced.  I also found the Chinese 140 textbook to have really excellent units on Chinese culture, though a bit dated.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the heavy use of Google Docs was a good strategy. Additionally, the individual Zoom session things on Thursday were a clever way of getting in extra speaking practice. Sometimes it is a bit hard to understand what people are saying over Zoom, but Im not sure what could be done about that.
I think  did her absolute best given the circumstances, which I completely appreciate and am thankful for!
I really liked the Thursday small section classes. It allowed for more speaking time and more time to work on pronunciation. It was nice to get focused attention once a week.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. My Chinese knowledge and fluency have increased dramatically this semester, especially after taking CHNS 130.

Chinese at Yale is a great experience. The Chinese teachers just want you to learn, and I certainly did a lot. I started in L1 from scratch, where I did very poorly, but if you are willing to keep at it you will be rewarded greatly and you will improve drastically.
Anyone looking to turn their Chinese from an academic endeavor into something they could use in real life should take this class.

I would definitely recommend this course, its extremely well organized, and the professorsof course Xu Laoshi especiallyare incredibly understanding and supportive. The Chinese program here is truly wonderful!
Yes! If you're serious about learning Chinese, this is an amazing class. It's a lot of work though, so you have to be committed.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar 4-5 times per week. Rarely recorded.
Additionally, there were weekly tutorial sessions with a TF.
Office hours, 30 minutes tutorial session also virtual
Virtual seminar 4 days a week and virtual small section (2-3 students) 1 day a week.
